ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] One more question
ygData.msgSnippet: Jeff, File nasa.cti specifies many species, but does not specify any phase that uses these species.  If you want to create an ideal gas mixture using these

From: David Goodwin <dgoodwin@...>
Subject: Re: [cantera] One more question
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=44728387; y=DkqIJuDokHfcc1fYb5y18Mtp06AhES49dpAIJTryfCQC
X-Yahoo-Profile: dggoodwin

Jeff,

File nasa.cti specifies many species, but does not specify any phase 
that uses these species.  If you want to create an ideal gas mixture 
using these species, you can do so by adding and "ideal_gas" entry to 
the file. See how this is done in file gri30.cti, for example.

If file nasa.cti contained only gaseous species, you could simply 
import all of them into your gas mixture with an entry like this, which 
could be in some other cti file.

ideal_gas(name = "gas",
                    elements = "H C O N Ar",
                    species = "nasa: all",
                    options  = "skip_undeclared_elements")

This will create a gas mixture of all species in nasa.cti that contain 
only the elements H, C, O, N, and/or Ar.  Unfortunately nasa.cti 
contains condensed-phase species too, like H2O(L) and H2O(S).  So if 
you want to do this, you would need to first create an edited version 
of nasa.cti that contains only the gaseous species. Alternatively, you 
can just list explicitly every species you want to include, as is done 
in gri30.cti.

As far as the temperature problem -- if you are using gri30.cti, then 
the valid temperature range for the gas mixture is set by the species 
with the highest minimum temperature, and the one with the lowest 
maximum temperature.  Even species that have zero mole fraction or 
extremely small mole fraction are considered when determining the valid 
temperature range.  In gri30.cti, the species CH3O has a maximum 
temperature of 3000 K.  If you want to do computations at higher 
temperature, you could remove this species from the phase (edit 
gri30.cti, or create a copy with a different file name) if it is not 
important for what you are computing.

Dave



On Jun 7, 2005, at 11:00 AM, csmnofbobs wrote:

> Dear Dave,
> Sorry to keep bothering you with these simple questions.  I can not
> figure out how to use data from nasa.cti without pasting the data I
> want into a new cti file.  Another student here using Cantera told me
> that in the equil demo, all he had to do was replace gri30.cti with
> nasa.cti and it worked fine.  When I try this, I get the following
> error:
>
> Procedure: xml_findByName
> Error:   name phase not found
>
> Error in ==> XML_Node.findByName at 4
> index = ctmethods(10, 9, root.id, name);
>
> Error in ==> Solution.Solution at 32
>   node = findByName(doc,'phase');
>
> Error in ==> IdealGasMix at 39
>        s = Solution(a);
>
> Error in ==> equiltest at 12
>    gas = IdealGasMix('nasa.cti');
>
> I made sure that nasa.cti and gri30.cti are in the same directory,
> and I checked to make sure that the species I am using have entries
> in nasa.cti.  What could be the problem?
>
> Thank you very much for your help,
> Jeff Miller
